article: Today's students learn more in school than just reading,writing and arithmetic. They also learn how to _ .More and more students are using _ means to get good grades in order to get into top _ .Increasingly,tomorrow's leaders are today's cheaters. Over the last decade,the number of students cheating academically has _ dramatically. Duke University conducted a(n) _ of 50,000 universities and 18,000 high school students in America. More than 70 percent of the students _ to having cheated.However,10 years ago,only 56 percent of the students cheated. This _ extends far beyond the US. In Asia,where students face great _ to excel ,the cheating problem is especially _ .In many Asian countries,a student's performance is measured _ by exam scores. And admission to a top school depends on passing standardized tests. This test driven culture makes cheating an easy way for students to get _ in a super competitive academic system. Last year,24 students in Taiwan _ chances and ended up in prison _ they were caught cheating on the University Entrance Exam. The students received answers to test questions _ cell phones and other electronic devices . But the pressure to perform well on tests isn't the only thing turning _ into cheaters. Today's students use text messaging to send each other test _ .Some post questions from standardized tests on Internet bulletin boards . Students in Asia, for example ,have posted questions from the TOEFL and the GRE.
